subject: Re: Media Collective Initiative

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Media Collective Initiative
triggerMessage.body:
Hey Creator,

Thanks for reaching out to R√òDE! We're excited to connect with you and
can‚Äôt wait to see the incredible content you‚Äôll create using our
top-of-the-line microphones and audio gear. Trusted by professionals,
artists, and creators around the world, we‚Äôre here to support your creative
journey.

Whether you decide to produce a full video about R√òDE or include a brief
brand integration, the choice is entirely up to you. We value your creative
freedom and want you to make the content in your own unique style.

Just a quick reminder: The gear is yours to keep at no cost, and we‚Äôll also
compensate you for creating and sharing content that features our products.

Here‚Äôs how to get started:

Visit  https://rodecommunity.com , choose the gear that works best for your
project, and fill out the form with your shipping details.

After reviewing your request, one of our campaign managers will contact you
to confirm your gear selection, discuss your rates, and go over the
specifics of your video. You'll also have the opportunity to share your
rate card and finalize the payment details.

We‚Äôre excited to see your creativity in action and are thrilled to be part
of your content creation!

Looking forward to collaborating,
The R√òDE Team

subject: Re: Early Access + YouTube Collaboration Opportunity with Lovable

triggerMessage.subject: Re: Early Access + YouTube Collaboration Opportunity with Lovable
triggerMessage.body:
Hey there!

Just wanted to quickly follow up in case our last note got buried.

We‚Äôre launching a major upgrade to the Lovable
<https://lovable.link/hayley> agent
next week and are finalizing a small group of creators to get early access
and publish YouTube content around the launch. Videos are planned to go
live *starting* *next Wednesday through the following week*, so we‚Äôre
locking things down pretty quickly here.

If you‚Äôre interested, feel free to send over your media kit and rates ‚Äî or
we're happy to jump on a quick call if you‚Äôd like a technical overview
first.

Either way, appreciate your time!

Best,
Hayley

triggerMessage.subject: Sponsorship Inquiry: Dedicated Video for Verdent (Parallel AI Agents)
triggerMessage.body:
Hi,

I‚Äôm reaching out from Verdent¬†(verdent.ai<https://www.verdent.ai/>) to discuss a potential sponsorship for your channel. We believe your audience of developers would value a tool built specifically for parallel execution.

Context Preservation:¬†Switch between tasks seamlessly with full context preserved in the Standalone App.

Workflow:¬†Transparent "Plan‚ÜíCode‚ÜíVerify" steps in VS Code for error-free results.

Content:¬†You are encouraged to compare Verdent with other "vibe coding" tools.

Next Steps:¬†If this aligns with your content schedule, please let us know your rate card¬†or a quote for a dedicated video. We‚Äôd be happy to discuss how we can make this work for you.

Best regards,
Evelyn

triggerMessage.body:
Hey Creator,

Thanks for reaching out to R√òDE! We're excited to connect with you and
can‚Äôt wait to see the incredible content you‚Äôll create using our
top-of-the-line microphones and audio gear. Trusted by professionals,
artists, and creators around the world, we‚Äôre here to support your creative
journey.

Whether you decide to produce a full video about R√òDE or include a brief
brand integration, the choice is entirely up to you. We value your creative
freedom and want you to make the content in your own unique style.

Just a quick reminder: The gear is yours to keep at no cost, and we‚Äôll also
compensate you for creating and sharing content that features our products.

Here‚Äôs how to get started:

project, and fill out the form with your shipping details.

After reviewing your request, one of our campaign managers will contact you
to confirm your gear selection, discuss your rates, and go over the
specifics of your video. You'll also have the opportunity to share your
rate card and finalize the payment details.

We‚Äôre excited to see your creativity in action and are thrilled to be part
of your content creation!

Looking forward to collaborating,
The R√òDE Team

triggerMessage.body:
Hello!

I am just getting started and trying to understand what might be wrong, i'm
in the first lesson in the directory
src/010-typescript-in-the-build-process/011-compile-typescript-to-javascript.solution.

Here are my versions:

pnpm 8.15.6
node 24.13.0
tsc 5.9.3

When I try to open the file in the browser, my console says:
example.js:5 Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token 'export' example.js:5

I'd like to make sure I get this working so I don't continue on with some
weird version issue or tsconfig issue. I think I've followed along as the
videos indicate, so I'm not sure if I've missed a step?

Corey

This is a module system issue, not a version problem. Your compiled JavaScript has export statements, but browsers need a module-aware script tag to understand them.
In your HTML file, change:
<script src="example.js"></script>
To:
<script type="module" src="example.js"></script>
The type="module" tells the browser to treat the file as an ES module, which supports import/export syntax.
If that doesn't match what the lesson expects, the alternative is changing your TypeScript compiler settings to output a different module format (like CommonJS or a bundled file), but adding type="module" to the script tag is the typical fix here.

Hello!



I'm an aspiring backend dev wanting to master Typescript. I have some backend TS experience, and some years working in Java at a large tech company.



I purchased the Pro Complete series when it was on sale in December, and I'm finally getting around to looking through it more closely. It feels quite a bit over my head currently, and I see one section on React that is not relevant to the work I'll be doing. I'm wondering, from your perspective, how relevant is the rest of the Pro Complete series to a backend-only TS dev (API design/implementation, database connection, etc)? I'm not planning to author any TS libraries, but will likely work for SaaS companies designing and implementing their backends. I'm wondering if the Essentials series will be sufficient for me.



Thanks,

Jack

Given my current situation of being out of work for six months, $198 is still quite a high hurdle for me to clear right now.

Is there any way to generate a specific code that applies a further discount to the India regional price, or perhaps a different way to process this so I can get closer to a manageable amount?

Siva

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Bart≈Çomiej Wojcieszek has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Hi Matt,
I Really love what you do! (also the shirts!)
I'm planning to buy your AI course soon.
The workshop is too expensive for me right now.

Keep up the good work!
Erez


On Thu, Jan 22, 2026 at 7:17‚ÄØPM Matt Pocock (AI Hero) <matt@aihero.dev>
wrote:

> Hey Erez,
>
> The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives
> available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI
> coding world.
>
> Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants.
> You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for
> Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
>
> But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers
> are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback
> mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created.
> Without constant babysitting.
>
> It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple,
> learnable pattern.
>
> *I‚Äôm running **a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/92uxvv0wgxfnh64wv7kh9hzoxm933bwh22llp/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>
> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers
> because this is hands-on. You‚Äôll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching
> me code.
>
> Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll leave with:
>
>    - Your own bash loop running
>    - Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
>    - Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
>    - The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
>
> By 1 PM, you‚Äôll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.
>
> *Sign-ups are open now.* Limited spots, and we‚Äôve got a discount running
> through Feb 5th. Grab yours before they sell out.
>
> The full details are here, including what actually breaks, why this works
> now (and didn‚Äôt before), and exactly what you need to bring.
> *Secure Your Seat*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/92uxvv0wgxfnh64wv7kh9hzoxm933bwh22llp/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>
>
> See you on February 11.
>

> You can also unsubscribe

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

The Fresh Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Community Forum is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Inside Flyball

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Town Hall meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Claude Code running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

The Fresh Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Community Forum is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Inside Flyball

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Town Hall meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Claude Code running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Open Library API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* The Design & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

The Fly.io Team

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Jason Wilbur has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Organizer
team@aihero.dev
team@aihero.dev

Guests
(Guest list has been hidden at organizer's request)

Invitation from Google Calendar: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/

You are receiving this email because you are subscribed to calendar notifications. To stop receiving these emails, go to https://calendar.google.com/calendar/r/settings, select this calendar, and change "Other notifications".

Forwarding this invitation could allow any recipient to send a response to the organizer, be added to the guest list, invite others regardless of their own invitation status, or modify your RSVP.

Learn more https://support.google.com/calendar/answer/37135#forwarding

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. Right there, right then.Working in groups. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. Hi Matt/AI Hero team,

Excited for the course! I have a few questions below so that I'm best prepared:

> What you need to bring Technical requirements:
>
> - GitHub account with a repo you can work on

Does this repo need to be public, or can it be private work-related?
Better if my repo is full-stack, front-end, or back-end?
Any other guidance on the repo (which programming language, webapp or mobile app, etc.) for the smoothest 4 hours? I have flexibility and am asking because I'll be creating the repo for the course.

> - Any one of these AI coding CLIs installed and working:
>
> - Claude Code (Opus 4.5)
> - OpenCode
> - Copilot CLI
> - Codex (GPT 5.2)

Do you always stick with a specific agent while Ralphing? With my legacy pre-Ralph HITL Cursor AI ways, I would find even the smartest agents (Opus 4.5 and GPT 5.2) can struggle or hit a dead-end while the other smart agent can sometimes quickly solve, so at times I flip agents. Perhaps you never encountered this, or perhaps those clear PRDs of yours make the problem far less or non-existant.

Thanks!
Jon

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Milan Stojanovic has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

triggerMessage.subject: Declined: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
Milan Stojanovic has declined this invitation with a note:
"Declined because I am unavailable at this time."

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

El jue, 22 ene 2026 a las 17:46, Matt Pocock (AI Hero) (<matt@aihero.dev>)
escribi√≥:

> Hey Luis,
>
> The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives
> available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI
> coding world.
>
> Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants.
> You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for
> Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
>
> But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers
> are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback
> mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created.
> Without constant babysitting.
>
> It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple,
> learnable pattern.
>
> *I‚Äôm running **a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0uknzmq77f6h5zw07gtlho9x0577a8hddpp4/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>
> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers
> because this is hands-on. You‚Äôll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching
> me code.
>
> Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll leave with:
>
>    - Your own bash loop running
>    - Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
>    - Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
>    - The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
>
> By 1 PM, you‚Äôll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.
>
> *Sign-ups are open now.* Limited spots, and we‚Äôve got a discount running
> through Feb 5th. Grab yours before they sell out.
>
> The full details are here, including what actually breaks, why this works
> now (and didn‚Äôt before), and exactly what you need to bring.
> *Secure Your Seat*
> <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0uknzmq77f6h5zw07gtlho9x0577a8hddpp4/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx>

subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)

triggerMessage.subject: Accepted: Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph @ Wed Feb 11, 2026 9am - 1pm (PST) (team@aihero.dev)
triggerMessage.body:
totaltypescript.com@roncya.com has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Guests

Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Arkadius Marchut has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

wrote:

> Hey Kevin Youkhana,
>
> The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives
> available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI
> coding world.
>
> Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants.
> You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for
> Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
>
> But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers
> are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback
> mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created.
> Without constant babysitting.
>
> It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple,
> learnable pattern.
>
> *I‚Äôm running **a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST*

> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers

>
>    - Your own bash loop running

>    - Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
>    - The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
