Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
Wednesday Feb 11, 2026 ‚ãÖ 9am ‚Äì 1pm
Pacific Time - Los Angeles



Half-day live workshop ‚Ä¢ February 11, 9 AM PST ‚Ä¢ Limited to 40 developers ‚Ä¢ üéâ **{percentOff}% off** ‚Äî Sale ends ! Only  left.The Ralph  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Geoffrey Huntley figured out the pattern. Matt Pocock validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a name‚ÄîRalph (yeah, like Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, because of course it does)‚Äîand developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasks‚Äîreal tasks, not toy examples‚Äîand create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Reserve Your SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Claude Code, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundation‚Äîonce it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lie‚Äîyou'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessing‚Äîit's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Hi Matt,
Sounds fantastic!
Price is on the edge what I can afford right now but trying to find a way next days.
Most important thing is : not sure if I can attend the workshop live. 
Would there be a recording available I could watch later?

Thanks for the update and looking forward to a new self paced workshop in the future regarding this topic!

Martin

> On 22. Jan 2026, at 15:20, Matt Pocock (AI Hero) <matt@aihero.dev> wrote:
> 
> Hey ,
> 
> The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI coding world.
> 
> Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants. You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.
> 
> But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created. Without constant babysitting.
> 
> It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple, learnable pattern.
> 
> I‚Äôm running a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST <https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vu3qe8zxzc9h9ne680hlhvze4k55hnh77003/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers because this is hands-on. You‚Äôll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching me code.
> 
> Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll leave with:
> 
> Your own bash loop running
> Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
> Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
> The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want
> By 1 PM, you‚Äôll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.

That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just execute‚Äîit validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Hooking Up Ralph To Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manually‚Äîit's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually execute‚Äînot theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Subject: Live Autonomous AI Agents with Ralph Workshop (very limited seats)
To: Scott <s@scottarnold.org<mailto:s@scottarnold.org>>



Hey Scott,

The future of AI coding is a loop. It‚Äôs one of the simplest primitives available to developers, but we‚Äôve been criminally underusing it in the AI coding world.

Instead, we‚Äôre stuck in that frustrating cycle with AI coding assistants. You ask for Feature A, get half a solution, manually fix it, ask for Feature B, and it breaks Feature A. Rinse, repeat.

But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening right now in production: developers are setting up agents that run in loops with structured feedback mechanisms. They point them at GitHub backlogs. Real PRs get created. Without constant babysitting.

It‚Äôs called the Ralph Wiggum technique, and it‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a simple, learnable pattern.

I‚Äôm running a live workshop on February 11 at 9 AM PST<https://7751c435.click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8u8mez84guqh6x9mz3hvhqzd58rraoh99mmp/dphehmued0v29ncm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYWloZXJvLmRldi9zL3JhbHBoLXdvcmtzaG9wLTAx> to teach you exactly how to build it. We‚Äôre capping at 40 developers because this is hands-on. You‚Äôll be debugging YOUR code, not just watching me code.

Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll leave with:

  *   Your own bash loop running
  *   Feedback mechanisms that let agents catch their own mistakes
  *   Your GitHub backlog wired up to actually execute tasks
  *   The PRD structure that makes agents do what you actually want

By 1 PM, you‚Äôll have real PRs being generated from your actual issues.

Sign-ups are open now. Limited spots, and we‚Äôve got a discount running through Feb 5th. Grab yours before they sell out.

> On 20. 1. 2026, at 13:24, Vojta Holik <vojta@egghead.io> wrote:
> 
> made more progress on the page here: https://www.aihero.dev/events/turn-ai-agents-into-autonomous-software-engineers-with-ralph
> 
> 
>> On 20. 1. 2026, at 9:32, Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com> wrote:
>> 
>> Yep, nice
>> 
>> On Mon, Jan 19, 2026 at 9:05‚ÄØPM Joel Hooks <team@aihero.dev <mailto:team@aihero.dev>> wrote:
>>> Turn AI Agents Into Autonomous Software Engineers with Ralph
>>> 
>>> -joel
>>> 
>>>> On January 19, 2026 at 12:57 AM PST vojta@egghead.io <mailto:vojta@egghead.io> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> does anyone have any good title suggestions, please? :) preview: https://www.aihero.dev/events/turn-ai-agents-into-autonomous-software-engineers~ztc6x?allowPurchase=true (copy is still WIP)
>>>> 
>>>> 
>>>> ‚Äì Vojta
>>>> 
>>>>> On January 14, 2026 at 5:47 PM GMT+1 alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Okay so we're gonna be honest here that there's a very mixed message: 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 1 - On one hand, this is "useful for a lot of people" and the reason to react to it NOW is because of the buzz/attention it's getting and more specifically, that YOU are getting around it. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 2 - On the other hand, you'd rather a small group and not looking to make a lot of money, happy with 6 people. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> So...which is it? :)
>>>>> 
>>>>> I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more "fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact." 
>>>>> 
>>>>> If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. Maybe having a 4th pillar (in addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."
>>>>> 
>>>>> However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy, Matt, your audience, and the team?" then I we need to resolve this contradiction as quickly as possible!
>>>>> 
>>>>> No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" - question is if Ralph is that or not? 
>>>>> 
>>>>> On Wed, Jan 14, 2026 at 7:55‚ÄØAM Matt Pocock <mattpocockvoice@gmail.com <mailto:mattpocockvoice@gmail.com>> wrote:
>>>>>> I totally defer to Joel on this. I'm no expert on pricing.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I would say that I would actually prefer a smaller group. I don't necessarily want it to devolve into a long workshop because that's more tedious to facilitate and also takes us further away from what the actual workshop will be.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Not looking to make money out of this workshop. I'd be perfectly happy with six people. Though obviously I can probably facilitate up to 40.
>>>>>>

conversationHistory.body:
Hey all,

One question I had yesterday that slipped my mind was the following:

I'm picturing the Ralph cohort when we get there as slightly less
interactive than previous cohorts. There will still be some interactive
exercises and playgrounds, but because Ralph is mostly conceptual, it's
going to feel more like I'm inspiring you to try things rather than
teaching you APIs.

How does this translate into a live workshop setting? All the live
workshops I've ever done have been extremely practical, where most of the
work is done in small groups, autonomously working through prepared
material.

I have some ideas of my own here, but I would love to get your thoughts -
especially since A&A are experts in this.

Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the
thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."

The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing
them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and
report back what worked, what didn't, etc.

For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are
really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you
actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh
I want to apply this to my own XYZ."

The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar
to most but not their domain expertise.

The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle
details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees.

I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are
more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the
mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple
but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph
too!)

In our case that's things like having people do customer research on
freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you
aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally
foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own
expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction.

We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling
attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on
their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher.

So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of
"familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily
something they do every day in their work/life."

Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then
reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that
gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that
same process looks like on their own thing.

Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up?

In our case it's solo work that they bring back for peer and teacher
feedback.

Our full loop is:
- 5 minute solo exercise BEFORE they learn the technique, sort of a set up
to show them that they need to pay attention. They might get okay results
but basically nobody nails it and that's by design.
- discuss what went well in that mini exercise, what didn't
- actual lesson
- larger full exercise now that they learned it. Usually 10-15 mins of solo
work
- return to class and volunteer for a hot seat where we ask the class for
observations about what they see, and then we provide teacher
feedback/notes/critique

I imagine a similar loop, if not these specific steps, could def be
translated for your stuff!

Hey Matt!


The workshop plan sounds good to me. 


A couple things:


We sent our proposal to Joel and we suggest $199-249 for this half-day workshop, but based on your goals you've stated above, we think we should revise that to $99-129. Please don't take this the wrong way, we're not saying it doesn't have the value! 


Think of it as a "doorbuster." Something to lure people in with a no brainer price.


This will help you bring in a wider audience, appeal to many more people than just the ones already super hype about Ralph. Instead of preaching to the crowd, as it were. Somebody who just heard about it will likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will do it for $399. 


Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying from you. 


Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from you again!


The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings' price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?" 


If you price it at $400, that's almost as much as somebody would pay for your week-long cohort, with discounts.


And Ralph is not a big, sweeping thing, general thing, compared to what you teach in those cohorts. Right now, it's very niche. And in our experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the field is still new.


This doesn't close the door on offering a higher-tier Ralph offering later. 


You don't have to add this to your library, even. It could be a one-off special event.


So, especially considering this is a quick launch you want to use to draw in the audience from your appearances, $99-129 is a price that makes an easy sell to the widest audience and will leave people feeling like they got a great value.


Lastly, let's not call it a cohort, which makes it sound like a multi-day course. It's a 1-day workshop. :) 


Amy

‚Äî
Amy Hoy

stackingthebricks.com

react to it NOW is because of the buzz/attention it's getting and more
specifically, that YOU are getting around it.

lot of money, happy with 6 people.

I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more
"fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact."

*If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. *Maybe having a 4th pillar (in
addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free
play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his
batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."

*However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy,
Matt, your audience, and the team?"* then I we need to resolve this
contradiction as quickly as possible!

No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" -
question is if Ralph is that or not?

Okay so we're gonna be honest here that there's a very mixed message: 




1 - On one hand, this is "useful for a lot of people" and the reason to react to it NOW is because of the buzz/attention it's getting and more specifically, that YOU are getting around it. 



2 - On the other hand, you'd rather a small group and not looking to make a lot of money, happy with 6 people. 



So...which is it? :)



I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more "fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact." 



If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. Maybe having a 4th pillar (in addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."



However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy, Matt, your audience, and the team?" then I we need to resolve this contradiction as quickly as possible!



No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" - question is if Ralph is that or not?

>>>> 2 - On the other hand, you'd rather a small group and not looking to make a lot of money, happy with 6 people. 
>>>> 
>>>> So...which is it? :)
>>>> 
>>>> I'm wondering if the Ralph thing is less "good for the business" and more "fun experimental stuff I want to do and maybe has a bigger impact." 
>>>> 
>>>> If so, that's fine, let's treat it as such. Maybe having a 4th pillar (in addition to the 3 we mentioned yesterday) of "fun, fully Matt-driven free play experiments that don't need much from the team but recharge his batteries and MAYBE give us advantages for other things."
>>>> 
>>>> However if the question is "what's best for the business and by proxy, Matt, your audience, and the team?" then I we need to resolve this contradiction as quickly as possible!
>>>> 
>>>> No matter what I think it'd be wise for build in some "free play" - question is if Ralph is that or not? 
>>>>

>>>>>>

Somebody who just heard about it will likely open their wallet for $99. Fewer will do it for $199. Very few will do it for $399. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Since your workshop can support more people, since it won't be very interactive ‚Äî more of a talk, really ‚Äî you don't need to limit seats, and could use this to potentially get lots of people into the habit of buying from you. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Once somebody's bought from you once, they're very likely to buy from you again!
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> The other elements to the price are "comparison to your other offerings' price" and "how easy is Ralph to sell?"

>>>>>>

And in our experience so far, selling niche "branches" off the AI tree is not working as well as more general whole project approaches. Makes sense, because the field is still new.
>>>>>>

>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>> - actual lesson

>>>>>>>>>>> Yeah, that sounds great. Concretely, what are you giving people during those sessions? Are you saying, "Okay, go into breakout rooms and work in groups to try this out?" Or are you saying, "Let's have five minutes of quiet on the line where we work on these questions individually?" 
>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>> On Tue, Jan 13, 2026 at 11:36‚ÄØAM Alex Hillman <alex@indyhall.org <mailto:alex@indyhall.org>> wrote:
>>>>>>>>>>>> Awesome question - I think there are a few potential answers here but the thing that comes to mind is thinking in terms of "simulations."
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> The thing that most reliability inspires people to try things is seeing them work first hand on small but relatable demos that they can try and report back what worked, what didn't, etc. 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> For example, in 30x500 we have a number of Sales Safari exercises that are really designed less to teach you the mechanics and more to get you actually TRYING it with the goal of seeing the results that make you go "oh I want to apply this to my own XYZ."
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> The things that helped is intentionally choosing examples that are familiar to most but not their domain expertise. 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> The reason here is that people would get in their heads about subtle details and their own biases, and struggle to see the forest for the trees. 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> I think this is a pretty universal challenge when teaching things that are more conceptual like customer research which isn't so much about the mechanics but the practice of getting good at a process that seems simple but packs a lot of power if you use it correctly (which sounds like Ralph too!)
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> In our case that's things like having people do customer research on freelancers or DIY kitchen remodelers or cat owners because even if you aren't that thing, almost everyone knows someone who is so it's not totally foreign conceptually BUT ALSO they aren't bringing all of their own expectations and biases into the exercise as a distraction. 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> We think of these demos as "safe sandboxes" to experiment without feeling attached to the outcome, as compared to if they were starting by working on their own audience where the stakes of getting it wrong were higher. 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> So for Ralph, I'd be thinking about use cases that are in the overlap of "familiar enough to recognize the value" but also "not necessarily something they do every day in their work/life."
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Giving people those practice examples and instructions to complete, then reflect on what worked and what didn't, is a powerful learning loop that gets people trying, feeling a win, and getting excited to see what that same process looks like on their own thing.
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> Does that make sense and resonate? Any new question it opens up? 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>>>>>

triggerMessage.body:
Good morning,

I hope this message finds you well.

I'm reaching out from *Everyday Software SL* to kindly request the invoice
corresponding to *Purchase Order No. POWS00000300*. The invoices refer to
the Learning budget Manfred Miravitllas.

As of today, we have not yet received the document, and we need it to
proceed with our internal administrative process.

We would appreciate it if you could share the invoice at your earliest
convenience, or confirm if it has already been sent to
noreply.invoices@factorial.co.

Additionally, please ensure that the PO number is included on the invoice
and that each invoice is sent as a separate PDF file.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
*Finance Team*
Everyday Software SL

Project Permanent Deletion Warning


Dear Developer,

Your Google Cloud project aerobic-gift-484511-f6 was shut down on January 16, 2026 11:59:01 AM UTC.

Shut-down projects and the data stored in them may be recovered for a limited time before the projects are permanently deleted. If you'd like to recover your project, you must cancel the project's permanent deletion before February 15, 2026 11:59:01 AM UTC.

To recover your shut-down project:

Visit the Resources pending deletion page.
Select the project you want to recover, and click Restore.
In the confirmation dialog, click Restore.


If you cannot recover your project by following the instructions above, you can try restoring it using the gcloud undelete command.

If you take no action by February 15, 2026 11:59:01 AM UTC, you will be unable to recover your project.

If you have any questions, please visit Google Cloud Platform Resource Manager Documentation or contact Google Cloud Platform Support.
